title: Tōtaranui
text:
Tōtaranui is a 1 km long beach and the site of a large campsite in the <a href="Tasman%20Region">Tasman Region</a> of <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> administered by the <a href="Department%20of%20Conservation%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Department of Conservation</a> (DOC).
It is located in <a href="Abel%20Tasman%20National%20Park">Abel Tasman National Park</a> toward the northern end of the <a href="Abel%20Tasman%20Track">Abel Tasman Track</a> and is often used as a starting or finishing point for the walk.
Tōtaranui is noted for the golden colour of its sand, more intense than other beaches in the Park, the result of a high content of <a href="orthoclase">orthoclase</a> minerals in the eroded granite sands of the vicinity.
The New Zealand <a href="Ministry%20for%20Culture%20and%20Heritage">Ministry for Culture and Heritage</a> gives a translation of "many trees" for .
History.
The <a href="Ng%C4%81ti%20T%C5%ABmatak%C5%8Dkiri">Ngāti Tūmatakōkiri</a> <a href="iwi">iwi</a>, having been forced out of <a href="Queen%20Charlotte%20Sound%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Queen Charlotte Sound / Tōtaranui</a> by <a href="Ng%C4%81ti%20Kuri">Ngāti Kuri</a>, settled north of the sounds along the coast and may have brought the name Tōtaranui with them.
Once a farming settlement, the only permanent residents now are DOC staff. During summer the population swells by up to 1000 campers plus hikers on the track. Water taxi services from <a href="Marahau">Marahau</a> link Tōtaranui with other localities around the Park coastline, while a road links Tōtaranui with <a href="T%C4%81kaka">Tākaka</a> via <a href="Pigeon%20Saddle">Pigeon Saddle</a>.
Farming ceased after the foundation of the Abel Tasman National Park in 1942 and forest has been allowed to naturally regenerate through <a href="Leptospermum%20scoparium">manuka</a> and <a href="Kunzea%20ericoides">kanuka</a> to its original mix of <a href="southern%20beech">southern beech</a> and <a href="lowland%20podocarp">lowland podocarp</a>.
